column7: Supervisors: Prof. Gavin T. L. Brown & Dr Kane Meissel
column8: Thesis: Sources of Sample Bias in PISA: Selectivity and Effort Differences between Shanghai and New Zealand
column9: The Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) is arguably one of the most influential international large-scale assessments and Shanghai in 2009 and 2012 outperformed the world in mathematics, reading, and science literacy. However, the legitimacy of such a comparison is questionable if sample bias exists among the jurisdictions. Two possible biases were evaluated in the thesis by comparing Shanghai with New Zealand: the similarity of tested population and the degree of effort in test-taking when a country's repuation is at stake.
